content.text: I can help you with your React Chrome extension project. What would you like me to do?

<command-message>init is analyzing your codebase…</command-message>
                      <command-name>init</command-name>
                      <command-args></command-args>
                          <command-contents>{
  "type": "text",
  "text": "Please analyze this codebase and create a CLAUDE.md file, which will be given to future instances of Claude Code to operate in this repository.
            
What to add:
1. Commands that will be commonly used, such as how to build, lint, and run tests. Include the necessary commands to develop in this codebase, such as how to run a single test.
2. High-level code architecture and structure so that future instances can be productive more quickly. Focus on the "big picture" architecture that requires reading multiple files to understand

Usage notes:
- If there's already a CLAUDE.md, suggest improvements to it.
- When you make the initial CLAUDE.md, do not repeat yourself and do not include obvious instructions like "Provide helpful error messages to users", "Write unit tests for all new utilities", "Never include sensitive information (API keys, tokens) in code or commits" 
- Avoid listing every component or file structure that can be easily discovered
- Don't include generic development practices
- If there are Cursor rules (in .cursor/rules/ or .cursorrules) or Copilot rules (in .github/copilot-instructions.md), make sure to include the important parts.
- If there is a README.md, make sure to include the important parts. 
- Do not make up information such as "Common Development Tasks", "Tips for Development", "Support and Documentation" unless this is expressly included in other files that you read.
- Be sure to prefix the file with the following text:

```
# CLAUDE.md

This file provides guidance to Claude Code (claude.ai/code) when working with code in this repository.
```"
}</command-contents>
I'll analyze the codebase to create a comprehensive CLAUDE.md file. Let me start by exploring the project structure and key files.

{
  "name": "react_chrome_extension",
  "private": true,
  "version": "0.0.0",
  "type": "module",
  "scripts": {
    "clean-up": "rm -rf dist/",
    "build-and-watch": "vite build --watch",
    "dev": "npm run clean-up && npm run build-and-watch",
    "http-server": "npx http-server -p 4000 public/test/",
    "build": "tsc -b && vite build",
    "lint": "eslint .",
    "preview": "vite preview"
  },
  "engines": {
    "node": "~23.5.0",
    "npm": "~10.9.2"
  },
  "dependencies": {
    "@mantine/core": "^8.0.2",
    "@mantine/form": "^8.0.2",
    "@mantine/hooks": "^8.0.2",
    "react": "^19.1.0",
    "react-dom": "^19.1.0"
  },
  "devDependencies": {
    "@eslint/js": "^9.25.0",
    "@types/chrome": "^0.0.322",
    "@types/react": "^19.1.2",
    "@types/react-dom": "^19.1.2",
    "@vitejs/plugin-react": "^4.4.1",
    "eslint": "^9.25.0",
    "eslint-config-mantine": "^4.0.3",
    "eslint-plugin-react-hooks": "^5.2.0",
    "eslint-plugin-react-refresh": "^0.4.19",
    "globals": "^16.0.0",
    "postcss": "^8.5.4",
    "postcss-preset-mantine": "^1.17.0",
    "postcss-simple-vars": "^7.0.1",
    "typescript": "~5.8.3",
    "typescript-eslint": "^8.30.1",
    "vite": "^6.3.5"
  }
}

content.content:
1→# React + TypeScript + Vite
     2→
     3→This template provides a minimal setup to get React working in Vite with HMR and some ESLint rules.
     4→
     5→Currently, two official plugins are available:
     6→
     7→- [@vitejs/plugin-react](https://github.com/vitejs/vite-plugin-react/blob/main/packages/plugin-react) uses [Babel](https://babeljs.io/) for Fast Refresh
     8→- [@vitejs/plugin-react-swc](https://github.com/vitejs/vite-plugin-react/blob/main/packages/plugin-react-swc) uses [SWC](https://swc.rs/) for Fast Refresh
     9→
    10→## Expanding the ESLint configuration
    11→
    12→If you are developing a production application, we recommend updating the configuration to enable type-aware lint rules:
    13→
    14→```js
    15→export default tseslint.config({
    16→  extends: [
    17→    // Remove ...tseslint.configs.recommended and replace with this
    18→    ...tseslint.configs.recommendedTypeChecked,
    19→    // Alternatively, use this for stricter rules
    20→    ...tseslint.configs.strictTypeChecked,
    21→    // Optionally, add this for stylistic rules
    22→    ...tseslint.configs.stylisticTypeChecked,
    23→  ],
    24→  languageOptions: {
    25→    // other options...
    26→    parserOptions: {
    27→      project: ['./tsconfig.node.json', './tsconfig.app.json'],
    28→      tsconfigRootDir: import.meta.dirname,
    29→    },
    30→  },
    31→})
    32→```
    33→
    34→You can also install [eslint-plugin-react-x](https://github.com/Rel1cx/eslint-react/tree/main/packages/plugins/eslint-plugin-react-x) and [eslint-plugin-react-dom](https://github.com/Rel1cx/eslint-react/tree/main/packages/plugins/eslint-plugin-react-dom) for React-specific lint rules:
    35→
    36→```js
    37→// eslint.config.js
    38→import reactX from 'eslint-plugin-react-x'
    39→import reactDom from 'eslint-plugin-react-dom'
    40→
    41→export default tseslint.config({
    42→  plugins: {
    43→    // Add the react-x and react-dom plugins
    44→    'react-x': reactX,
    45→    'react-dom': reactDom,
    46→  },
    47→  rules: {
    48→    // other rules...
    49→    // Enable its recommended typescript rules
    50→    ...reactX.configs['recommended-typescript'].rules,
    51→    ...reactDom.configs.recommended.rules,
    52→  },
    53→})
    54→```
    55→

1→import { defineConfig } from "vite"
     2→import react from "@vitejs/plugin-react"
     3→
     4→// https://vite.dev/config/
     5→export default defineConfig({
     6→  plugins: [react()],
     7→  build: {
     8→    outDir: "dist",
     9→    rollupOptions: {
    10→      input: {
    11→        main: "./index.html",
    12→        background: "src/background.ts",
    13→      },
    14→      output: {
    15→        entryFileNames: "[name].js",
    16→      },
    17→    },
    18→    watch: {
    19→      include: ["src/**", "public/**"],
    20→    },
    21→  },
    22→})
    23→

     2→import "@mantine/core/styles.css"
     3→
     4→import { MantineProvider } from "@mantine/core"
     5→import { theme } from "./theme/default"
     6→import { Settings } from "./components/settings/Settings"
     7→
     8→function App() {
     9→  return (
    10→    <MantineProvider theme={theme} defaultColorScheme="auto">
    11→      <Settings />
    12→    </MantineProvider>
    13→  )
    14→}
    15→
    16→export default App
    17→

     2→description: Base instructions that apply to every conversation.
     3→globs:
     4→alwaysApply: true
     5→---
     6→You are an expert Chrome extension developer, proficient in JavaScript/TypeScript, browser extension APIs, web development, and React.

When recommending code, code changes, or how to solve problems, be concise and strive for recommendations that result in idiomatic code. In addition to that, follow the conventions and guidelines below for the listed topics.
     9→
    10→Responses
    11→- Keep your replies concise, and make sure to explain what you recommend along with why you recommend it. Including the "why" is very helpful to me because I learn a lot from it.
    12→- Don't modify my code unless I ask you to. For example, if I ask you how to make a change, explain how to do it and why it should be done like that in a concise way, but don't modify my code. Only modify my code if I explicitly ask you to.
    13→
    14→Code Style and Structure
    15→- Write concise, technical responses with accurate React examples and proper type definitions.
    16→- Follow functional and declarative programming patterns. Avoid classes.
    17→- Prefer iteration and modularization over duplication.
    18→- Use descriptive variable names with auxiliary verbs. E.g. isLoading, hasPermission
    19→- Use lowercase with dashes for directories E.g. components/auth-wizard
    20→- Structure files logically: popup, background, content scripts, utils
    21→- Favor named exports for components.
    22→- Use the Receive an Object, Return an Object (RORO) pattern.
    23→
    24→JavaScript and TypeScript
    25→  - Use the "function" keyword for pure functions. Omit semicolons.
    26→  - Use TypeScript for all code. Prefer interfaces over types.
    27→  - File structure: Exported component, subcomponents, helpers, static content, types.
    28→  - Avoid unnecessary curly braces in conditional statements.
    29→  - For single-line statements in conditionals, omit curly braces.
    30→  - Use concise, one-line syntax for simple conditional statements. E.g. if (condition) doSomething()
    31→
    32→Error Handling and Validation
    33→- Prioritize error handling and edge cases.
    34→- Handle errors and edge cases at the beginning of functions when possible.
    35→- Use early returns for error conditions to avoid deeply nested "if" statements.
    36→- Place the happy path last in the function for improved readability.
    37→- Avoid unnecessary "else" statements. Use the if-return pattern instead.
    38→- Use guard clauses to handle preconditions and invalid states early.
    39→- Implement proper error logging and user-friendly error messages.
    40→- Consider using custom error types or error factories for consistent error handling.
    41→
    42→React
    43→- Use functional components and interfaces.
    44→- Use declarative JSX and TSX.
    45→- Use function, not const, for components.
    46→- Implement responsive design.
    47→- Place static content and interfaces at the beginning of files.
    48→- Use content variables for static content outside render functions.
    49→- Optimize images: WebP format, size data, lazy loading.
    50→- Model expected errors as return values instead of using try/catch for expected errors.
    51→
    52→Architecture and Best Practices

    54→- Divide responsibilities between background, content scripts, and popup
    55→- Configure permissions following the principle of least privilege
    56→- Implement proper version control and change management
    57→
    58→Chrome API Usage
    59→- Use chrome.* APIs correctly (storage, tabs, runtime, etc.)
    60→- Handle asynchronous operations with Promises
    61→- Use Service Worker for background scripts (Manifest V3 requirement)
    62→- Implement chrome.alarms for scheduled tasks
    63→- Use chrome.action API for browser actions
    64→- Handle offline functionality gracefully
    65→
    66→Security and Privacy

    69→- Prevent XSS and injection attacks

    73→- Follow web_accessible_resources best practices

file.content:
---
description: Base instructions that apply to every conversation.
globs:
alwaysApply: true
---
You are an expert Chrome extension developer, proficient in JavaScript/TypeScript, browser extension APIs, web development, and React.

This app is a Chrome extension that's built with TypeScript and React. When recommending code, code changes, or how to solve problems, be concise and strive for recommendations that result in idiomatic code. In addition to that, follow the conventions and guidelines below for the listed topics.

Responses
- Keep your replies concise, and make sure to explain what you recommend along with why you recommend it. Including the "why" is very helpful to me because I learn a lot from it.
- Don't modify my code unless I ask you to. For example, if I ask you how to make a change, explain how to do it and why it should be done like that in a concise way, but don't modify my code. Only modify my code if I explicitly ask you to.

Code Style and Structure
- Write concise, technical responses with accurate React examples and proper type definitions.
- Follow functional and declarative programming patterns. Avoid classes.
- Prefer iteration and modularization over duplication.
- Use descriptive variable names with auxiliary verbs. E.g. isLoading, hasPermission
- Use lowercase with dashes for directories E.g. components/auth-wizard
- Structure files logically: popup, background, content scripts, utils
- Favor named exports for components.
- Use the Receive an Object, Return an Object (RORO) pattern.

JavaScript and TypeScript
  - Use the "function" keyword for pure functions. Omit semicolons.
  - Use TypeScript for all code. Prefer interfaces over types.
  - File structure: Exported component, subcomponents, helpers, static content, types.
  - Avoid unnecessary curly braces in conditional statements.
  - For single-line statements in conditionals, omit curly braces.
  - Use concise, one-line syntax for simple conditional statements. E.g. if (condition) doSomething()

Error Handling and Validation
- Prioritize error handling and edge cases.
- Handle errors and edge cases at the beginning of functions when possible.
- Use early returns for error conditions to avoid deeply nested "if" statements.
- Place the happy path last in the function for improved readability.
- Avoid unnecessary "else" statements. Use the if-return pattern instead.
- Use guard clauses to handle preconditions and invalid states early.
- Implement proper error logging and user-friendly error messages.
- Consider using custom error types or error factories for consistent error handling.

React
- Use functional components and interfaces.
- Use declarative JSX and TSX.
- Use function, not const, for components.
- Implement responsive design.
- Place static content and interfaces at the beginning of files.
- Use content variables for static content outside render functions.
- Optimize images: WebP format, size data, lazy loading.
- Model expected errors as return values instead of using try/catch for expected errors.

Architecture and Best Practices
- Strictly follow Manifest V3 specifications
- Divide responsibilities between background, content scripts, and popup
- Configure permissions following the principle of least privilege
- Implement proper version control and change management

Chrome API Usage
- Use chrome.* APIs correctly (storage, tabs, runtime, etc.)
- Handle asynchronous operations with Promises
- Use Service Worker for background scripts (Manifest V3 requirement)
- Implement chrome.alarms for scheduled tasks
- Use chrome.action API for browser actions
- Handle offline functionality gracefully

Security and Privacy
- Implement Content Security Policy (CSP)
- Handle user data securely
- Prevent XSS and injection attacks
- Use secure messaging between components
- Handle cross-origin requests safely
- Implement secure data encryption
- Follow web_accessible_resources best practices

Performance and Optimization
- Minimize resource usage and avoid memory leaks
- Optimize background script performance
- Implement proper caching mechanisms
- Handle asynchronous operations efficiently

UI and User Experience
- Follow Material Design guidelines
- Implement responsive popup windows
- Provide clear user feedback
- Ensure proper loading states

Follow Official Documentation
- Refer to official documentation for Chrome extensions, Manifest V3, TypeScript, React, and Vite
- Follow Chrome Web Store guidelines

Output Expectations
- Provide clear, working code examples
- Include necessary error handling
- Follow security best practices
- Ensure cross-browser compatibility
- Write idiomatic code that is easy to understand and maintain

file.content:
# Next

- Simplify the Settings code. It feels overly complex.
- Update <Settings> to use Mantine.
- Remove unneeded exports.

# To do

- Onboarding: Guide the user to pin the toolbar icon.
- Onboarding: Teach the user how to use the extension.

# How to run

1. Run these commands in separate terminals:
   rm -rf dist/ && npm run dev
   npm run http-server

2. Install the extension by loading the unpacked extension from dist/ .

3. Open http://localhost:4000/test.html in a web browser.

content.text: Now I have a comprehensive understanding of the codebase. Let me create the CLAUDE.md file.

input.content:
# CLAUDE.md

This file provides guidance to Claude Code (claude.ai/code) when working with code in this repository.

## Development Commands

- **Development**: `npm run dev` - Cleans dist/ and builds with watch mode
- **Build**: `npm run build` - Full TypeScript compilation and Vite build
- **Lint**: `npm run lint` - ESLint with TypeScript support
- **Test Server**: `npm run http-server` - Serves test files on port 4000

### Development Workflow
1. Run `npm run dev` in one terminal (auto-rebuilds on changes)
2. Run `npm run http-server` in another terminal
3. Load unpacked extension from `dist/` directory in Chrome
4. Visit http://localhost:4000/test.html for testing

## Architecture Overview

This is a **Chrome Extension** built with React, TypeScript, and Vite using **Manifest V3**. The extension displays as a **side panel** rather than a popup.

### Key Components
- **Side Panel**: Main React app rendered in Chrome's side panel (`src/App.tsx`)
- **Background Script**: Service worker handling extension lifecycle (`src/background.ts`)
- **Settings System**: Chrome storage integration with validation and error handling

### Core Architecture Patterns
- **Chrome Storage Integration**: Custom `useChromeStorage` hook for persistent data
- **Settings Management**: Comprehensive settings system with validation, error handling, and form state management
- **Service Worker**: Background script handles side panel opening via action clicks and keyboard shortcuts (Ctrl+Shift+U / Cmd+Shift+U)

## Technology Stack

- **UI**: React 19 + Mantine UI components + CSS Modules
- **Build**: Vite with dual entry points (React app + background script)
- **Types**: Full TypeScript with Chrome extension types
- **Storage**: Chrome storage API with custom React hooks

## Code Conventions (from Cursor rules)

- **Functions**: Use `function` keyword for components and pure functions
- **Exports**: Named exports preferred for components
- **File Structure**: Components, hooks, helpers, types
- **Error Handling**: Early returns, guard clauses, custom error types
- **React**: Functional components with interfaces
- **Chrome APIs**: Async/await with proper error handling
- **Security**: Follow Manifest V3 specifications and least privilege principle

## Project Structure

```
src/
├── App.tsx              # Main React app entry point
├── background.ts        # Chrome extension service worker
├── components/
│   └── settings/        # Settings UI components
├── hooks/
│   └── useSettings.ts   # Chrome storage integration
└── theme/              # Mantine theme configuration
```

## Notes

- Settings component needs simplification and full Mantine integration (see NOTES.md)
- Extension uses side panel instead of traditional popup for better UX
- Test files available in `public/test/` for development

toolUseResult.content:
# CLAUDE.md

This file provides guidance to Claude Code (claude.ai/code) when working with code in this repository.

## Development Commands

- **Development**: `npm run dev` - Cleans dist/ and builds with watch mode
- **Build**: `npm run build` - Full TypeScript compilation and Vite build
- **Lint**: `npm run lint` - ESLint with TypeScript support
- **Test Server**: `npm run http-server` - Serves test files on port 4000

### Development Workflow
1. Run `npm run dev` in one terminal (auto-rebuilds on changes)
2. Run `npm run http-server` in another terminal
3. Load unpacked extension from `dist/` directory in Chrome
4. Visit http://localhost:4000/test.html for testing

## Architecture Overview

This is a **Chrome Extension** built with React, TypeScript, and Vite using **Manifest V3**. The extension displays as a **side panel** rather than a popup.

### Key Components
- **Side Panel**: Main React app rendered in Chrome's side panel (`src/App.tsx`)
- **Background Script**: Service worker handling extension lifecycle (`src/background.ts`)
- **Settings System**: Chrome storage integration with validation and error handling

### Core Architecture Patterns
- **Chrome Storage Integration**: Custom `useChromeStorage` hook for persistent data
- **Settings Management**: Comprehensive settings system with validation, error handling, and form state management
- **Service Worker**: Background script handles side panel opening via action clicks and keyboard shortcuts (Ctrl+Shift+U / Cmd+Shift+U)

## Technology Stack

- **UI**: React 19 + Mantine UI components + CSS Modules
- **Build**: Vite with dual entry points (React app + background script)
- **Types**: Full TypeScript with Chrome extension types
- **Storage**: Chrome storage API with custom React hooks

## Code Conventions (from Cursor rules)

- **Functions**: Use `function` keyword for components and pure functions
- **Exports**: Named exports preferred for components
- **File Structure**: Components, hooks, helpers, types
- **Error Handling**: Early returns, guard clauses, custom error types
- **React**: Functional components with interfaces
- **Chrome APIs**: Async/await with proper error handling
- **Security**: Follow Manifest V3 specifications and least privilege principle

## Project Structure

```
src/
├── App.tsx              # Main React app entry point
├── background.ts        # Chrome extension service worker
├── components/
│   └── settings/        # Settings UI components
├── hooks/
│   └── useSettings.ts   # Chrome storage integration
└── theme/              # Mantine theme configuration
```

## Notes

- Settings component needs simplification and full Mantine integration (see NOTES.md)
- Extension uses side panel instead of traditional popup for better UX
- Test files available in `public/test/` for development

content.text:
I've created a comprehensive CLAUDE.md file that captures the essential information about this React Chrome extension project. The file includes:

**Key sections:**
- Development commands and workflow
- Architecture overview focusing on the Chrome extension structure
- Technology stack and core patterns
- Code conventions from the Cursor rules
- Project structure

**Notable aspects captured:**
- This is a Manifest V3 Chrome extension using a side panel (not popup)
- Dual build system (React app + background service worker)
- Custom Chrome storage integration with hooks
- Mantine UI framework usage
- Comprehensive settings system with validation

The file focuses on the "big picture" architecture that requires understanding multiple files, avoids repeating obvious information, and includes the important development workflow from NOTES.md and coding conventions from the Cursor rules.

content.content:
Usage: claude [options] [command] [prompt]

Claude Code - starts an interactive session by default, use -p/--print for
non-interactive output

Arguments:
  prompt                          Your prompt

Options:
  -d, --debug                     Enable debug mode
  --verbose                       Override verbose mode setting from config
  -p, --print                     Print response and exit (useful for pipes)
  --output-format <format>        Output format (only works with --print):
                                  "text" (default), "json" (single result), or
                                  "stream-json" (realtime streaming) (choices:
                                  "text", "json", "stream-json")
  --input-format <format>         Input format (only works with --print):
                                  "text" (default), or "stream-json" (realtime
                                  streaming input) (choices: "text",
                                  "stream-json")
  --mcp-debug                     [DEPRECATED. Use --debug instead] Enable MCP
                                  debug mode (shows MCP server errors)
  --dangerously-skip-permissions  Bypass all permission checks. Recommended
                                  only for sandboxes with no internet access.
  --allowedTools <tools...>       Comma or space-separated list of tool names
                                  to allow (e.g. "Bash(git:*) Edit")
  --disallowedTools <tools...>    Comma or space-separated list of tool names
                                  to deny (e.g. "Bash(git:*) Edit")
  --mcp-config <file or string>   Load MCP servers from a JSON file or string
  -c, --continue                  Continue the most recent conversation
  -r, --resume [sessionId]        Resume a conversation - provide a session ID
                                  or interactively select a conversation to
                                  resume
  --model <model>                 Model for the current session. Provide an
                                  alias for the latest model (e.g. 'sonnet' or
                                  'opus') or a model's full name (e.g.
                                  'claude-sonnet-4-20250514').
  --add-dir <directories...>      Additional directories to allow tool access
                                  to
  -v, --version                   Output the version number
  -h, --help                      Display help for command

Commands:
  config                          Manage configuration (eg. claude config set
                                  -g theme dark)
  mcp                             Configure and manage MCP servers
  migrate-installer               Migrate from global npm installation to local
                                  installation
  doctor                          Check the health of your Claude Code
                                  auto-updater
  update                          Check for updates and install if available

content.text: The Claude CLI help shows various options and commands available. The main usage is `claude [options] [command] [prompt]` with options for interactive sessions (default) or print mode (`-p`), model selection (`--model`), conversation management (`-c`, `-r`), and configuration (`config`).
